triples.name: Explainable artificial intelligence
triples.relevance: The paper develops and evaluates explainable decision-support tools for legal reasoning with interpretable explanations grounded in legal argumentation.

triples.name: Legal reasoning
triples.relevance: The paper models and automates legal reasoning about cases from the European Court of Human Rights using computational argumentation methods.

triples.name: Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights
triples.relevance: The paper models a specific legal domain (right to fair trial) as the basis for their decision-support tool.

triples.name: Argumentation framework
triples.relevance: The paper uses computational models of argument from argumentation theory to formally model the legal domain and generate explanations.

triples.name: Decision support system
triples.relevance: The paper designs and implements practical decision-support tools for legal case decision-making with evaluation of effectiveness and usability.

triples.name: Artificial intelligence and law
triples.relevance: The paper demonstrates an application of AI to legal informatics by building trustworthy AI tools for a real-world legal domain with critical end-user needs.
